The Last of Us 2 represents how games sh: While not *quite* as tight in its storytelling as the first game (both Abby and Ellie’s individual sections drag a little) the ambition of this sequel is incredible and something that I haven’t seen in a story-driven game to this level before. Naughty Dog took risks in their storytelling that ultimately paid off in their intention to make an entire player-ship question their motives and morals throughout. For all of the complaints about this being a game that ‘disrespects’ Joel\, ultimately this wound up being a love-letter to Joel\, while somehow simultaneously understanding how his actions could drive somebody to revenge\, allowing us to understand their motives at the same time. Gameplay is much improved from the first\, with general encounters being considerably more engaging\, and set-pieces\, especially the Scar Island Escape allowing for the gameplay to be leagues ahead of the first game. It’s also beautiful enough to almost qualify as next-hen\, and ultimately will be remembered as *the* game of this generation of PlayStation games. Masterpiece.… Expand
